page.title: 09Tavistock Wharf.
page.content: Work began on the{canal and wharf} in 1803 and was completed in June 1817 at a cost of Â£130,000. The wharf was built for loading and unloading soft fruit, clay, ore and kersey wool from the barges. These products were stored in the Wharf buildings. The wharf buildings now provide accommodation for plumbing and building suppliers, the Guides and Quakers, as well as a collection point for old newspapers. {Restoration plans}have been made for the Wharf. Existing buildings will house a museum, working blacksmith, cooper, smithy and lacemaker. Restored buildings will be used as a cafe and workshops for a pottery, weaver of kersey wool and soft fruit preservers. It is planned that{barges}will travel on the canal.Hopefully it will be completed by 1990.
